citations.narrative:
During a routine inspection of the facility, USDA Inspectors identified two areas in need of repair:
• At Golden Dome, the covered patio, behind the outdoor harbor seal pools, had a vertical board used to support the
ceiling, that was no longer attached to the wall. The lower portion of the board had started to decay and the nails that
fastened it to the wall detached from rotted section.
• At Top Deck, an area was noted where water was dripping down between the stadium and the outside of the tank, onto
the lower observation window below. The metal frame and bolts that attach the glass to the tank had areas of layered,
flaking rust.
Enclosures that fall into states of disrepair may no longer be able to safely contain the animals and can lead to health and
well-being hazards to the animals within.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for marine mammals must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury, to contain the animals within the facility, and to restrict entrance of unwanted animals. Both issued were corrected
at the time of inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility has created an avian enrichment plan, but the plan does not address the special needs of nestlings, chicks or
fledglings. The facility houses bonded pairs of penguins who are currently setting on eggs and have successfully hatched
flamingos in the past. While these birds have been identified, their additional enrichment needs have not been
documented.
Failure to develop and document a plan for special consideration birds may result in inadequate or intermittent care in
promoting and addressing needs for nestlings, chicks or fledglings.
Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement adequate to
promote the psychological well-being of birds. Certain birds must be provided special attention regarding enhancement of
their environment, based on the needs of the individual species and/or individual bird and in accordance with the
instructions of the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by November 8, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

narrative:
3.101(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
During a routine inspection of the facility, USDA Inspectors identified two areas in need of repair: 
• At Golden Dome, the covered patio, behind the outdoor harbor seal pools, had a vertical board used to support the 
ceiling, that was no longer attached to the wall. The lower portion of the board had started to decay and the nails that 
fastened it to the wall detached from rotted section. 
• At Top Deck, an area was noted where water was dripping down between the stadium and the outside of the tank, onto 
the lower observation window below. The metal frame and bolts that attach the glass to the tank had areas of layered, 
flaking rust. 
 
Enclosures that fall into states of disrepair may no longer be able to safely contain the animals and can lead to health and 
well-being hazards to the animals within. 
 
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for marine mammals must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury, to contain the animals within the facility, and to restrict entrance of unwanted animals. Both issued were corrected 
at the time of inspection. 
3.154(c)(1) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility has created an avian enrichment plan, but the plan does not address the special needs of nestlings, chicks or 
fledglings. The facility houses bonded pairs of penguins who are currently setting on eggs and have successfully hatched 
flamingos in the past. While these birds have been identified, their additional enrichment needs have not been 
documented.  
 
Failure to develop and document a plan for special consideration birds may result in inadequate or intermittent care in 
promoting and addressing needs for nestlings, chicks or fledglings. 
 
Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species appropriate plan for environmental enhancement adequate to 
promote the psychological well-being of birds. Certain birds must be provided special attention regarding enhancement of

their environment, based on the needs of the individual species and/or individual bird and in accordance with the 
instructions of the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by November 8, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n

species.scientific: Ara, Anodorhynchus, Primolius, Diopsittaca spp hybrid

species.common: CONGO AFRICAN GREY PARROT / GRAY PARROT
